title: Norway’s largest public pension sheds all investments in Canada’s oilsands
text:
Kommunal Landspensjonskasse (KLP) sold US$33 million in equity holdings and US$25 million in bonds from companies with business in the oilsands, including Cenovus, Suncor, Imperial Oil and Husky, after the fund tightened the revenue limit its portfolio companies can pull from the oilsands from 30 per cent to five per cent. (National Observer)

Talking point: Jeanett Bergan, head of responsible investments at KLP, said the move was necessary to limit global warming to 1.5 C. Institutional investors in Norway are among those leading divestments in the oil and gas sector. In June, the country’s sovereign wealth fund—whose investments in Canada totalled US$28 billion at the time—sold off investments in companies that do oil and gas exploration unless they had renewable-energy operations to help counteract their emissions. KLP’s new policy goes a step further by cutting off oilsands companies, regardless of their clean-energy initiatives.
